segments.text: Hello and welcome to Veterans of the Valley.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I'm Tom Turbyville.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: You won't find a prouder Aggie than Joe Brewster.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Being an Aggie is in his blood.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: His father, his grandfather, his great uncle, his uncle, his sons, all fellow Aggies.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And like his father, Colonel Olin Finley Brewster, Joe Brewster served his country in combat.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Olin Brewster, a decorated soldier of the Battle of the Bulge in World War II.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Joe Brewster, a ground infantry fighter in the jungles of Vietnam and Cambodia.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: It's our pleasure to have Lieutenant Joe Brewster as our guest on Veterans of the Valley.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Joe, it's great to have you here.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: First, I want you to talk about Olin Finley Brewster, your dad.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I know you told me one time that there was probably not many officers that were more written about in World War II than Olin Brewster.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about your dad and what he did.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, my dad was a major
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: His promise came about in the Battle of the Bulge.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Pretty much the Germans tried their counteroffensive in December of 1944, trying to split the American Allied Forces to get to Antwerp.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And for their success, they had to go through several major road intersections.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And my dad was responsible for an area south of Antwerp, an area called Parker's Crossroads.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And they held this intersection for two or three days, keeping the German divisions back.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: But being right in the middle of a core boundary, one core unit pulled back to reset their lines.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The other core unit did not, which my dad was still left forward.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And the only reason he had to pull out was the Germans got in and around behind him.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So he was given the orders to pull back the best way he could.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Pulling forward, he lost several tanks.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Pulling backwards, he lost several tanks.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And he realized at that point in time that he wasn't going to be able to get his men out successfully unless they went ahead and destroyed the rest of their vehicles.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And he was able to march all his men out on Christmas Eve there in December 1944.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I know it's a story that you're very proud of, and you're very proud of him.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I know you lost him not too many years ago, but he was a person who you were very interested in his service and he in yours.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, he brought us kids up understanding two things.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Number one, we were going to be Aggies.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: My brother and I ended up being third-generation Aggies, come through NM.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And he also told us that we had an obligation to our country.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: and we would be soldiers.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And my brother just retired, full colonel, stationed down at Fort Sam down in Santon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: My military career didn't last as long as my dad's and my brother's.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: After spending a couple years in the active army and then a couple years, two or three years in inactive reserves, my service came to an end.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Not a day goes by that I don't think about it, but my dad pretty much set the pattern which us boys had to follow.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Let's talk about the path that brought you not only to A&M, but then into the service.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: It was a little bit unusual back in the mid-60s when you came to A&M.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: There was a brand new program then that still exists today.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about sort of the program that sent you through and to the military at A&M.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, my brother was already here at A&M.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He ended up being class of 66.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And it was my turn to come to A&M, but my freshman year, I didn't quite have the monies to...
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: come to the fine university here on the Brazos.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So I ended up spending a couple years at Temple Junior College over in Temple.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: At that time, I thought my dream of getting into core here at A&M had come to an end, but A&M started this new program called a two-year program where you could go to a summer camp between your sophomore and junior year in college.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And then you come in as a junior in the Corps, but naturally with freshman privileges.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And then you go to a second summer camp between your junior and senior year.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so because of this, it enabled me to go ahead and get my commission at Texas A&M University in a two-year time frame instead of a four-year time frame.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Indeed.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And you were a distinguished military student here at Texas A&M, is that right?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Yes, sir, that's correct.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I believe what system in that is, like I say, being a third generation Aggie, I knew a lot about A&M.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I knew a lot about the Corps.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I knew what was expected of me.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Also, my dad being in the military, I had gone out to Fort Hood with him on numerous occasions as a kid, so I understood the military ways.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The first camp I went to between my sophomore and junior year taught me basic military, not only to be able to march, be able to fire a weapon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I did things prior to coming into my junior year that a lot of the juniors in the Corps had not got to do yet.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So when it came time to teach in dismounted drill and doing things with weapons, I was often used as an instructor.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Then between my junior and senior year, I excelled at 4C Oklahoma and so that gave me an opportunity to be nominated for and receive this DMS and later DMG.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It also gave you the opportunity to choose your specialty in the Army or at least narrow it down and I know you said you
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: You put down infantry, armored, and artillery, and you got infantry.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Is that right?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, back then, you were required to put one combat branch, which would have been armored or infantry, artillery.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Then you put down two service branches, quartermaster, transportation.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was a little on the gung-ho side back then, so I wanted to go combat, so I put them down infantry, armored, and artillery.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Broke my dad's heart because he was armored, but I knew that I wanted to go infantry because Vietnam was going at the time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I couldn't see fighting in the jungles of Vietnam sitting in a half track or a tank.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I thought my chances were a lot better as an infantryman.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so that's the way I selected.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And the Army, based on that great wisdom, gave it to me.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You went to Ranger School.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Oh, I love Ranger School.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I knew that when I came through infantry officer basic at Fort Benning that, again, my path was towards Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I felt like the best insurance policy to have at the time is to take some of the better schools that the Army was offering.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I did the airborne jump school.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It was great for just getting out and running every morning and jumping out of an airplane, but I couldn't see its full usefulness in Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: But the ranger school taught small unit tactics, and it taught you what it was like to fight in jungle, where you spent two weeks in Dahloneca, Georgia doing mountain warfare, but then they took us down to Elgin Air Force Base, the jungles down in Florida.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And we spent two and a half weeks of maneuvering down there, and that gave me a really good experience of what I could expect when I got to Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You went to Fort Riley, Kansas for three months, I guess, for your final training before you went in country.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: 1970, I guess this was toward the latter years, actually, of the war.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: 1970, first week or first or second week of January, you were in country and you served for 11 months.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about when you first went there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And I'm going to let you just sort of go ahead and sort of talk about your 11 months in service in Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I know you talk about
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: that you had a guardian angel on you many times.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So just go with it and talk about your service in Nam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, one thing that I found out real quickly in Vietnam is it doesn't matter how good you are, a lot of it determines on how lucky you can also be.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I often refer to it as being the guardian angel.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: My first day out in the field, I was flown out with another lieutenant who was also being assigned to the same battalion I was being assigned to.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And also in a helicopter was a full colonel who happened to also be a Presbyterian minister.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So I felt like if you had to go into combat, that was probably the best person in the world to go in with.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: As I exited the helicopter at my first forward base, there was an officer waiting for me out on the pad, and I thought that was my welcome committee.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, I found out that was the lieutenant whose place I was taking.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I thought and was understanding that I would work with him up to a week to get a better grasp of what to expect of my troops and my platoon as well as the area of operation we'd be working in.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, he let me know immediately as he was boarding the helicopter that he thought his luck had run out and he was going back to the rear base and I was on my own.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: My dad had always told me that
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: look to your NCOs.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They are the backbone of the Army, and thank goodness my platoon had a crusty old NCO, E7, and he took me under his wing and he said, you know, Lieutenant, if you'll listen to me, I can get you through this.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so for the first two or three weeks, I pretty much listened to him, and I felt like a lot of my success came from him.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: But I was thrown into it almost immediately.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: After meeting my company commander and was introduced to my platoon and met a lot of the platoon members, we were out the second night that I was in country.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: and we had river boats that the Navy provided us to take us up, and we were forming an umbrella protection for Saigon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We were trying to interdict both forces as well as supplies coming in from Cambodia by either water routes or trail, jungle trails, and so we were supposed to interdict them by setting up ambushes at night and preventing them from moving through the area freely.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: My first night, we were set up, and normally you set up either a linear ambush with rear security or an L-shaped ambush with rear security, depending on the terrain and what you're trying to ambush, a trail or a waterway.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: As we got in late, though, we did not have an opportunity to check out the terrain, so we just formed a wagon-wheel type of ambush, figuring any direction, 360, we'd be ready for it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: After about an hour on the ground, hour and a half on the ground, I was tapped by one of the members of my...
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: unit saying, Lieutenant, they're out there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I said, who's out there?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He informed me that it sounded like VC or MVA had found our position and he suggested we go on full alert.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: About that time, RTO also punched me and said, Lieutenant, the Toon Sergeant on the other side of the ambush says that he has movement out in front of him.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So I called my NCL and said, hey, this is my first night out here.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: What do you recommend?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He said, well, go to a full mad minute, which meant that everybody in our ambush would fire immediately at the same time for one full minute, which we did.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And sure enough, the NVAVC were out in front of us.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We received return fire.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We suffered four or five casualties at that time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We ourselves only found a few blood trails of the NVAVC.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It had no KIA that we could count for them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Since it was so late at night, since we could not move to another position successfully and safely, we were extracted that night.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And then we continued to do the same routine over the next couple of weeks.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The mad minute.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: This is your first really full night in command of the platoon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And how did you feel?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I mean, it must have been rather mind boggling for you to realize where you were and that this was the real thing.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: It's amazing how with all the training that I had done, both through infantry officer basic, ranger and airborne, that immediately when the first rounds were fired,
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: that I wasn't even aware of what I was doing.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: There was a mechanism that kicked in.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: My infantry platoon leader just said, quote, this is how it's done.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You have studied it over and over again.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Follow your intuition.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Your training will not take you the wrong direction.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I noticed that throughout my nine or ten months that I was out in the field, that every time a situation occurred, I'd fall back on that training, and the training was always successful.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It worked.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You talked to me earlier about that these troops in Vietnam, sometimes that they had to endure, for lack of a better word, several different leaders during a year because the officers were moved in and moved out of Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: They might get three or four.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: So you were placed in that situation to where you were a brand new leader for troops that had been there maybe a couple of tours.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about that and what that was like and the help that you got sort of being placed in that situation.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, it seemed that part of being in Vietnam was to stop communism, but it was also a training base for our young soldiers.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The platoon leaders, the first and second lieutenants, as well as the captains, was in a testing area.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They all, or a majority of them, were planning on making the Army, regular Army.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And they were all preparing for that big war that at some time in the future we thought we might have with either China or Russia.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So they were trying to give as many young officers a chance to be in command.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So when I got in country, most of the officers were being rotated out in three or four months.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: But Nixon in 1970 said, hey, we're going to start withdrawing troops.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So fewer and fewer troops were going.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So instead of me spending a normal three or four months in line, I ended up spending nine.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The problem with this rotation and everything is that you have an entry between 40 or 45 men.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You have an officer who comes in there and only spends three months, and he may be a West Point graduate, and that particular officer has his own way of doing things.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: After three months, he would be moved to the rear or to another position, and you might get an officer coming in who graduated from Arkansas ROTC or Texas A&M University.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Each one wanted to do it their way, and each time the platoon had to suffer through this gradual learning again.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, the only common base we had was the NCOs, in that if they had been in the military long enough, and if you normally had an E-6, E-7, they'd been in the military for probably five to ten years.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So they were the constant that went with each platoon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They would take the lieutenant aside and say, that will work if you're back stateside, it's not going to work here, lieutenant.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And if you had a good lieutenant, he would listen to them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And pretty much that's how we handled our situation for the first two months, one month, until I got my feet on the ground.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And after that, the constant was me.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And being allowed to stay with my unit for up to eight or nine months, it benefited our unit.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We were more cohesive during the nine, ten months that I was in the field.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: A lot of the casualties that occurred in Vietnam occurred from booby traps.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We got out in the field and we moved through jungles, we moved through water areas, we moved through Mitchelon rubber plantation.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: One thing we did, we moved with stealth.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We moved, we didn't go anywhere unless we took our time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We paid attention to the environment around us.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We would move, we would stop, we would listen, we would smell.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Then we'd move and do the same thing over and over again every 15 minutes.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And if you let your troops know what you were going to do that day, a lot of the units failed to tell the private or the point man, hey, this is our objective for the day.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Most of them just said go in that direction for about 2,000 to 3,000 meters, and then we're going to ambush tonight.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I would try to make sure that down to my lowest man, they knew what we were going to do that day.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They felt like we were part of the decision-making.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so that if, in fact, we hit anything along our way,
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: from point A to point B, they would say it was expected.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was told by the lieutenant that this is what to expect and they were more educated when it came to grasping the situation.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Lieutenant Brewster, you brought some pictures.

segments.text: I know you have a lot of photographs from your time in Vietnam and we are going to show some of them here as a matter of fact that Lieutenant Brewster has.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Go ahead and talk about the picture.

segments.text: What are we looking at there?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, this is a road from Conten.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: That's you on the right, by the way.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: That is me on the far right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And we are pulling a road security for trucks coming from Conten over to the Cambodian border.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And our job was to parallel this road and make sure the NVC...

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: There'd probably be another unit probably a half mile behind us doing the same thing to keep the NVA and VC from coming in behind my unit and planting mines before the trucks started bringing in their supplies to the fire support base.

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Now you're having some fun with some of the kids there in Vietnam.

segments.text: You know, we were pretty much day in, day out in the jungles working ambushes.

segments.text: But every once in a while, we had the enjoyment of getting to pull protection for a village.

segments.text: Typically, we would have in our company of three platoons, we'd have two platoons pulling an umbrella
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: security on the outside of the village and one of the platoons would stay inside the village and help maybe build buildings, build desks for the small kids.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We provided entertainment for them and here we're just taking the opportunity to let the kids know that we were friendly, we were easy going, we were not big giants who were going to hurt them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so we're doing a game of splits here and the kids found it very entertaining.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: That's you in the back there doing the major splits there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Here's a couple of other lieutenants.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was third platoon leader.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The gentleman in the middle was second platoon, and the gentleman on the far left was first platoon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: In Cambodia, both of them got shot.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Both survived.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: The one in the middle came back for a second time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: His injuries weren't so bad, but then about a month and a half later, two months later, he also got hit a second time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was the fortunate one who managed to always stay out of harm's way.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: That's that Gordon Angel I said was on my shoulder.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was in the same mix as they were.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: When we went into Cambodia, there was three-line platoon officers.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We had a forward observer and a commander, and of those officers, I was the only one who came back and escaped.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Okay, let's move on to the next photograph, another photograph of you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: That is a rice paddy during the summertime.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It's dried up, so they apparently don't have rice in there right now growing.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: During the wet seasons, monsoons, that would be filled up with water probably up to your ankle.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And typically, even during wet or dry time of season, you never walk on the berms or the high ground you see in the background.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: That's where the NVA or VC would set their booby traps.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We would walk through the water or through the flat part there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Now, what we're doing here is that we're probably getting ready to go in after spending a week or two out pulling ambushes.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And we always like to make sure that we shoot through our old
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: shells, our old weaponry, cleaning out your weapons.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You don't want to take back bullets that maybe got rusted or maybe got jammed or hit around while you were going through the jungle getting off helicopters.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So we would pretty much clean our weapons and then resupply ourselves when we got back to the base camp.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And actually we wouldn't use all our ammunition at this point because you never know on the way back
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: to your base camp, you might get shot down.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: But we would shoot maybe half our load here to clear our weapon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Plus, we'd cross train.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I would be shooting M79, getting used to it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Another guy would move over from his rifle over to the machine gun.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So we'd cross train so that if one person went down, somebody else could also use that weapon.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Okay, let's move on to the next one.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Now, this was actually back in the States during training in Colorado, right?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I just thought it was a great picture.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, it is, and you can tell that was not Vietnam, because look at the starched uniform.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You would not be wearing that over in the jungles of Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: When I came out after two years of the Army, I went into the reserves, and I didn't have to go active reserve because I had spent time in Vietnam, so I was under the title of inactive reserve, which meant that if I was needed,
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: at some summer camp for two weeks, I could be called up.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, this was a mech unit that came in out of Nebraska who did their train over at Fort Carson, Colorado.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So they called me up to come in.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They were a platoon leader and they had me go up there and spend two weeks.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so I was working with a mech unit.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: That's an armored personnel carrier.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And what you do, it's a little bit different than doing infantry.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: In infantry, you're normally very close together when you're moving through jungles.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You space out a little bit more in the open area.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: When you're working with mechanized units, you're looking more at conventional warfare, something you would expect to do if you were in Germany fighting in that terrain as opposed to Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Okay, let's move on to the next one.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: This next picture was actually taken from a book
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: that you supplied the picture.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I'm gonna let you talk about the book real quick, because we're running short on time, but this is a book written by a current professor at Blinn College about Cambodia.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And that is you on the right.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: That is correct.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: About five, six, seven years ago, I was reading one of the local paper here, and there was someone inquiring if you were an officer or an enlisted man that had fought in Cambodia during 1970, please get in touch with this person.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So I thought about it for a couple of days and gave him a call.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It was a lady who actually grew up in Cambodia.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Her dad had been Secretary of State or Secretary of Defense, and she grew up in the timeframe of the Kilmer Rouge, who took over Cambodia in the early 1970s through 75, the Killing Fields time.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And she wanted to find out some information about the American military activities in Cambodia.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I was able to provide her some information, which when the book was written, she did mention my name once or twice, which I felt very gratified for.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: But she was a great lady.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: She spent five, six years writing this book.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: It's now published and can be picked up at a lot of local bookstores.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: This is where we're coming down from Conten, heading down towards the Cambodian border.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We spent one or two days pulling security for transportation trucks along this route, and then we went into Cambodia itself to fight.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Okay.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Let's move on to, I believe, our last picture.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And there's your dad, and there you are sitting next to him.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And this was a time that he was honored in Louisiana, right?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about this.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, back in the 1960s, during the Cuban crisis, my dad, the 49th Army, was called up, headquartered out of Temple.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He was a battalion commander.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And they were sent down to Fort Polk, Louisiana.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And all the armored units of the 49th were called down there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He spent a full year down there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so this was probably about six, seven, eight years ago.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They were going to honor a plaque to the 49th, and he was requested to come down there, and he was sort of the honoree.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And it gave me an opportunity to spend time with my dad, hear more of the war stories that I heard as a kid.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And as you get older and you've experienced that war situation, you've been there, you can ask questions a little bit differently than if you've never seen combat.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So I was able now to go in there and find out specifically what did it feel like?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You know, a lot of generic terms you ask, you know, what was it like in a war?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And a person will give you a generic answer.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: But if you ask a specific question, like when that shrapnel buzzes by your head or you take casually, your hand is holding down a wound until the medics get there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: What went through your head?
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was now able to discuss that with him in sort of a soldier to soldier way.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Joe, you were awarded the Bronze Star Medal on two occasions for your action on two consecutive days, May 8th and 9th, 1970.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Talk about what happened those two days.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We went into Cambodia, and up until then, most of our combat was small unit back in Vietnam.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We got into Cambodia as a larger units fighting each other.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And we had...
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: landed our helicopters.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: My opportunity was the first opportunity to go in.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And as soon as we hit the ground, helicopters left, we were hit from the wood line by the NVA.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They were attacking a cache that was very important to them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We had to fight our way into the jungle for the next two or three days.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We unsuccessfully kept trying to take that cache and that particular bunker complex, which we finally did take.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: During that time frame, I spent a lot of time in the front, giving directions, pulling wounded men back, and the Army thought that maybe I deserved a Bronze Star for that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I'm sure there were a lot of soldiers that did a lot more than I did that deserved a Bronze Star, didn't get it, but somehow I got nominated for it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: On the next day or two later, we were bedwacked along one of the rivers there in Cambodia, getting ready to do another mission.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: and the Navy came down one of the rivers there, spotted us, and they had been ambushed several times the previous day, and they were a little bit on the touchy side, and apparently our higher command did not warn them that we were there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So they immediately opened fire with us with quad 50s, and they had an automatic 79 grenade launcher, and we started taking severe casualties.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And someone had to get communication with them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We did not have their radio frequency.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So someone had to get up and actually motion to them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We were Americans.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And I guess I drew the black bean because I ended up being the one that did it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And apparently, again, somebody thought I deserved something for that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Again, medals should have been more adjusted than deserved elsewhere, I'm sure.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We need to move along, but with about a month left in your service, you were sent to the 1st Cavalry, but then eventually sent back to the 25th.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And talk about the message that you got that the Chief of Staff wanted to see you and what he had to say to you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Well, the 25th Infantry Provision received orders they were going to return home in probably November, October, November of 1970.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: because I still had a little over a month left in country, I was not able to ship home with a lot of the troops.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I was sent to the first Cav, figuring I still had a month and a half left, and I could be of service to them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Went to their one-week school, and they realized, hey, you're a little still shoe sharp.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: You won't benefit us.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And by that time, I got orders to return back to the 25th Infantry.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Well, as soon as I hit the ground, there was a gentleman standing there.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: A lieutenant said that the chief of staff, full colonel, wanted to visit with me.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So I entered his office, and normally a lieutenant does not want to face the chief of staff.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: There's normally something very, very wrong.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: In this case, he had my file in front of him.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He indicated, well, you went through Ranger School, you went through Airborne, received a few medals.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: He said, you're exactly the person I'm looking for.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I said, oh, no, not one of these deep, sort of black missions they're going to send me on.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And it ended up being that he needed someone to take the vision colors of the 25th Infantry back to Schofield Barracks in Hawaii.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And they felt like that I was the right person to do that.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And it was quite an honor for me to receive the orders to do this.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I trained with about 30 other gentlemen.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: We brought all the regimental colors in.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Several of these troops had been Medal of Honor winners.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: So I got to hear their stories.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: They were quite the heroes.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And then in the middle of December, we flew into Schofield Barracks there in Hawaii, met by a band.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Then the next couple of days, the colors were transferred back to the 25th there in Hawaii.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I know that was quite an honor for you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: And it's something that probably of all your memories of your Vietnam experience, it was that at the end, bringing back the colors that is maybe the most meaningful to you.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: It is one that I'll always remember.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: I just that a lot of the soldiers that went to Vietnam did not have the great fortune I had of returning back to the United States.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Most of the soldiers came back home and most of them were not met at the airport.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: There were no bands or anybody congratulating them.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And yet here I was coming back with a band waiting for me.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Congratulations.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: And so that made me feel extremely well thought of.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Like, you know, my time in service was appreciated.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_01

segments.text: Joe Brewster, thank you very much for your service, and thank you for being here.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: I appreciate it.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Growing up in Temple, Joe Brewster was sure of two things.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: He would be an A&M cadet, and he would be a soldier.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: He served both roles with distinction, and that's definitely a family trait.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We thank Joe Brewster and all veterans for their service, and we thank our underwriter, First National Bank.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: For more stories of veterans, be sure to read Brazos Valley Heroes every Sunday in The Eagle.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: For Lieutenant Joe Brewster, I'm Tom Turberville.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: We'll see you next time on Veterans of the Valley.
segments.speaker: SPEAKER_00

segments.text: Thank you.
